page.title: 08LOCAL HISTORY OF HARVEL AREA
page.content: In Pre-Roman times long-distance trade crossed England using the easiest route. One of these followed the North Downs escarpment for many miles, and later the medieval Pilgrims Way followed this same track. It can still be traced,often as a bridleway, through the Holly Hill area. There is also a Ridge Track connecting Luddesdowne to the Pilgrims Way. This passes near the un-used Early-Norman Dode Church. The village of Dode was probably destroyed by the Black Death. Other ancient trackways include Old Commority and Heron Hill Lane. Many local buildings and churches are constructed with flints obtained from the hills where there are remains of Dene-holes. The wooded nature of the area probably led to coppicing and the charcoal industry in the middle Ages when Harvel originated.
